section.name: AgentBeans
section.p: AgentBeans are components of an agent which encapsulate access to the agent's environment and other essential functionalities.

The basic concepts of AgentBeans are implemented in the abstract class
AbstractAgentBean
and should be used wherever possible. These basic concepts include the lifecycle management and activity for AgentBeans. These two concepts are described in the following.

subsection.name: Lifecycle Handling in AgentBeans
subsection.p:
Like Nodes and Agents are subjected to the lifecycle (see Agent Lifecycle ) so do the AgentBeans. There are several hook methods available in
AbstractAgentBean
which should be overridden if required. The purpose of these methods are listed below:

li.p: Should contain initialisation code that ensures the functionality of the AgentBean. In this stage you should avoid the interaction with other AgentBeans as they might not have been initialised yet!
Code which activates the functionality of the AgentBean should be placed here. Interaction with other AgentBeans is possible.
This method is called when the current AgentBean is due to be stopped. So code which deactivates the AgentBean's functionality should be placed here. Interaction with other AgentBeans is possible.

Before being removed from the Agent this method gives the opportunity to free every resource acquired by and to finish all initiated processions of this AgentBean. Afterwards, the state of this AgentBean should be the same as before initialisation!

subsection.p: Note: If you override some of the aforementioned hook methods, you should call the super methods in the appropriate order. This means you should invoke super.doInit() and super.doStart() before and super.doStop() and super.doCleanup() after your code!

subsection.name: Activity in AgentBeans
subsection.p: By default, each AgentBean is a passive one, meaning that it is only requested for action or knowledge procession. Nevertheless you have the possibility to declare your AgentBean active.

AgentBean activated by defining the execution interval through the configuration or by calling
setExecutionInterval(int)
Active AgentBeans should also override the
execute()
which does nothing by default.

Note: Currently two implementations of
IExecutionCycle
are available. The
SimpleExecutionCycle
schedules the action procession and the invocation of the execute methods in a pipelining fashion. This means, that actions and executions that take very long will delay all other computations within the same agent. You may look into the sources of
SimpleExecutionCycle
to get an idea of how this simple implementation works. A more sophisticated realisation of the interface is the
NonBlockingExecutionCycle
which invokes the action procession and execute methods in own threads using the thread pool of the agent node. This means, that actions and executions are allowed to invoke other actions synchronously or to wait for events, because they will not delay other computations within the agent.

subsection.name: Pre-defined Spring Configurations
subsection.p: There are Spring Bean definitions for the SimpleExecutionCycle and a SimpleAgent available. Please check de.dailab.jiactng.agentcore.conf.Agent.xml for further details.
